Entities.Name: Groundbreaker.solutions
Entities.Title: President / Chief Architect
Entities.Description:
Jason Lind serves as the President and Chief Architect at Groundbreaker Solutions LLC, where he leads multiple advanced technology initiatives in support of Department of Defense (DoD) modernization efforts. His work spans AI-driven analytics for cognitive warfare, domain-specific modeling and knowledge integration for naval combat systems, and blockchain-based supply chain risk management, all underpinned by rigorous compliance with defense standards and security protocols.

In projects such as “Archetypes and Analytics: Building AI-Driven Cognitive Warfare Assessment Tools,” Jason’s team leverages Large Language Models, sentiment analysis, and psychographic modeling to help identify and counter adversarial narratives. He combines theories like Speech Act Theory and Drama Theory with cultural frameworks (e.g., Hofstede’s Dimensions) to design AI tools capable of understanding the “emic” perspective—how local populations perceive and respond to information. By providing robust strategic planning support and real-time assessments of potential cognitive threats, he advances the next generation of influence and information operations. 

Jason also leads efforts to enhance naval combat system interoperability, as seen in “Project Sentient Nexus: AI-Driven Knowledge Integration for Combat System Interoperability.” Here, he spearheads the development of an AI-generated Domain Specific Model (DSM) capable of unifying disparate data formats, ontologies, and schemas such as NIEM, RDF/OWL, and STIX into a coherent, machine-readable framework. By deploying this AI-driven pipeline, Jason and his team streamline real-time data exchange among sensors, weapons, and command systems, enabling a more agile, integrated battlespace picture for U.S. Navy operations.

Additionally, Jason oversees the design and implementation of blockchain-based smart contracts to strengthen defense supply chains. Groundbreaker Solutions’ work on “Revolutionizing Defense Supply Chain Resilience” introduces a private, permissioned blockchain for improved traceability, automated contract enforcement, and near-instant verification of parts provenance. Jason’s depth of experience in enterprise architectures, large-scale data integration, and security frameworks ensures these solutions meet strict DoD regulations, safeguarding sensitive or classified information while improving supply chain transparency. 

Throughout these SBIR-focused initiatives, Jason’s leadership style emphasizes interdisciplinary research, real-time data ingestion, and secure, scalable platforms. By uniting AI, cybersecurity, and advanced data modeling techniques, he ensures Groundbreaker Solutions consistently delivers cutting-edge capabilities that address the DoD’s evolving challenges in modern warfare, logistics, and technology integration.

Entities.Name: Programming.Team
Entities.Title: Founder / Chief Architect
Entities.Description:
Programming.Team is built on a modern and highly scalable technology stack, leveraging ASP.NET Core for backend development and Blazor for the frontend, creating a seamless full-stack .NET environment. Unlike many applications that rely on JavaScript frameworks like React or Angular, Programming.Team uses Blazor, enabling developers to build interactive web applications entirely in C#. This eliminates the need for JavaScript in the frontend while ensuring better maintainability and a more cohesive development experience.

For the user interface, the application employs MudBlazor, a UI component library designed specifically for Blazor applications. MudBlazor provides a clean and modern design system with prebuilt components such as forms, tables, dialogs, and charts, streamlining the development of interactive and responsive web applications. This ensures that users have a smooth and visually appealing experience when interacting with the resume customization features.

To manage UI state and event-driven interactions efficiently, Programming.Team uses ReactiveUI, a reactive programming framework for .NET. This follows the MVVM (Model-View-ViewModel) pattern, making it easier to handle complex UI logic and data binding while keeping the frontend codebase modular and maintainable. ReactiveUI allows for seamless synchronization between UI components and backend logic, ensuring that changes in data are reflected dynamically across the application.

At the backend, ASP.NET Core serves as the primary engine for processing requests, managing authentication, handling resume generation, and integrating AI-powered features. The system leverages Entity Framework Core for database interactions, allowing efficient querying and management of user data while ensuring performance optimizations. 

A key feature of Programming.Team is its AI-driven resume tailoring, which uses ChatGPT-powered NLP (Natural Language Processing) to analyze job descriptions and map them to user-provided work histories. By extracting key skills and qualifications from job postings, the system helps users tailor their resumes dynamically, ensuring they align with hiring expectations and increase their chances of passing Applicant Tracking Systems (ATS). ChatGPT enhances this process by understanding the context of job descriptions and generating optimized summaries and skill matrices that highlight a candidate’s most relevant qualifications.

For document rendering, Programming.Team employs LaTeX, a powerful typesetting system that ensures professional and highly structured resume formatting. Unlike traditional document generation methods, LaTeX provides precision in layout and ensures that resumes are consistently formatted and ATS-friendly. Users can modify LaTeX templates to adjust resume styling and structure, and the system regenerates PDFs efficiently without additional processing costs.

To enable seamless deployment and maintain consistency across different environments, Programming.Team is containerized using Docker. This ensures that the application runs reliably across development, staging, and production environments, reducing compatibility issues and simplifying scaling. Additionally, Azure Pipelines is integrated for Continuous Integration and Continuous Deployment (CI/CD), automating testing, building, and deployment workflows. This allows for faster iteration cycles and ensures that new updates reach users with minimal downtime.

By combining Blazor, MudBlazor, ReactiveUI, ASP.NET Core, ChatGPT for AI-driven resume optimization, Entity Framework Core, LaTeX for PDF generation, Docker for containerization, and Azure Pipelines for CI/CD, Programming.Team provides a powerful and user-friendly solution for job seekers. The integration of ChatGPT enhances the platform’s ability to generate tailored, professional resumes dynamically, making it a valuable tool in an increasingly competitive job market. The technology stack ensures scalability, flexibility, and maintainability, allowing for continuous improvement and future feature expansion.

Entities.Name: UNofficial CYBERCOM
Entities.Title: Founder / Chief Architect
Entities.Description:
The UNofficial CYBERCOM project represents a novel approach to decentralized cybersecurity governance by integrating blockchain, DAOs (Decentralized Autonomous Organizations), and automated smart contract execution within a secure, transparent, and decentralized command structure. Unlike traditional cybersecurity models, which often rely on hierarchical decision-making and centralized authority, this initiative leverages blockchain immutability, self-executing governance, and collaborative cyber defense mechanisms to enhance efficiency and security. From a business logic perspective, the project aims to streamline bureaucratic processes, accelerate decision-making, and foster dynamic coalition-building among cybersecurity professionals, governmental agencies, and independent researchers.

At the core of the project is the DAO, implemented using Solidity smart contracts on an Ethereum-compatible blockchain. The DAO enables automated governance, ensuring that cybersecurity policies, incident responses, and resource allocation decisions are executed in a transparent, tamper-proof manner. Members of the DAO interact with governance mechanisms through secure on-chain voting, where consensus mechanisms determine cybersecurity actions, funding distribution, and operational directives. Nethereum, a .NET library, facilitates blockchain integration with the project's C# backend, enabling real-time interactions with smart contracts, transaction execution, and blockchain data retrieval without requiring JavaScript-based libraries.

A critical component of the project’s architecture is its Server-Side Blazor application, which provides an intuitive and secure interface for users to engage with the DAO. Unlike WebAssembly-based Blazor applications, Server-Side Blazor executes UI logic on the server, maintaining a persistent SignalR connection with clients. This approach ensures faster load times, centralized security enforcement, and streamlined resource consumption, making it ideal for enterprise-level cybersecurity operations. The Telerik UI component library further enhances the user experience by providing robust data grids, advanced charting, and interactive forms, allowing cybersecurity professionals to visualize blockchain transactions, analyze voting results, and manage governance workflows efficiently.

### Voting Architecture: Decentralized Decision-Making
One of the most critical aspects of the UNofficial CYBERCOM project is its voting architecture, which serves as the foundation for decentralized governance within the DAO. The project employs blockchain-based voting mechanisms to ensure secure, transparent, and fraud-resistant decision-making in cybersecurity operations. The voting system is implemented using Solidity smart contracts, which enforce immutable rules governing how proposals are created, debated, and approved.

The voting architecture consists of the following key components:
1. Proposal System: Members of the DAO can submit proposals related to cybersecurity policy changes, operational directives, fund allocations, and threat response strategies. Each proposal is recorded on the blockchain, ensuring a transparent and verifiable history of governance decisions.
   
2. Voting Mechanisms: The project supports multiple voting models, depending on the type of decision being made:
   - Quadratic Voting: To prevent wealth-based dominance, this system allows participants to allocate votes in a way that diminishes the influence of the largest stakeholders.
   - Token-Weighted Voting: Members holding governance tokens can vote proportionally based on their stake in the DAO.
   - Delegated Voting (Liquid Democracy): Members can delegate their voting power to more knowledgeable experts, ensuring that technical decisions are made by qualified stakeholders.

3. Consensus Rules & Thresholds: Different types of decisions require different approval thresholds. For example:
   - Routine operational decisions may require a simple majority (50%+1).
   - High-impact security decisions may require a two-thirds supermajority.
   - Emergency cybersecurity responses may require multisignature authentication from designated security council members.

4. Automated Execution via Smart Contracts: Once a proposal is approved, a Solidity smart contract automatically executes the decision. This prevents manual tampering or bureaucratic delays, ensuring that approved security measures or policy changes take effect immediately.

5. On-Chain Transparency & Auditing: Every vote is recorded immutably on the blockchain, making it impossible to alter past decisions. Participants can audit the history of governance actions, ensuring full accountability.

By integrating Solidity smart contracts with Nethereum for blockchain interactions, Blazor for secure and efficient user engagement, and Telerik UI components for intuitive governance dashboards, the UNofficial CYBERCOM project builds a highly scalable, secure, and transparent voting and governance system.

### Accelerating Bureaucracy & Enhancing Decision-Making
One of the project’s goals is to streamline traditional bureaucratic processes using blockchain automation. By eliminating the need for manual approvals, bureaucratic delays, and siloed decision-making, the DAO automates governance processes, ensuring that resources are allocated based on real-time consensus and verifiable blockchain records. This decentralized approach enhances trust, reduces the risk of corruption or mismanagement, and ensures that cybersecurity initiatives are executed without unnecessary delays. The integration of blockchain automation also prevents unauthorized tampering, ensuring the integrity of security operations.

On a more specific level, the project’s business logic is structured around three key operational layers: governance, resource management, and real-time incident response. The governance layer is responsible for policy-making, voting, and access control—all executed via Solidity smart contracts and enforced through Nethereum’s blockchain interactions. The resource management layer automates fund allocation, equipment provisioning, and personnel assignments using predefined DAO protocols. Finally, the real-time incident response layer enables automated cybersecurity threat mitigation, allowing coalition members to deploy security patches, share threat intelligence, and coordinate cyber defense strategies dynamically.

By integrating Blazor Server, Solidity, Nethereum, Telerik, and C#, the UNofficial CYBERCOM project builds a highly scalable, secure, and transparent cybersecurity framework. The decision to use Server-Side Blazor over WebAssembly reinforces the project's emphasis on centralized control over sensitive computations while maintaining a distributed governance model. The project thus serves as a pioneering model for decentralized cybersecurity governance, offering a future-proof solution for global cyber defense coordination, bureaucratic automation, and real-time decision-making in the digital age.

Entities.Name: Department of Defense
Entities.Title: USSF Freelance Architect
Entities.Description:
Jason was tasked with overhauling a critical C# ASP.NET MVC application for the United States Space Force, used to track instrumentation on weather balloons vital for atmospheric data collection and mission planning. The application, plagued by numerous bugs, architectural inefficiencies, and an outdated interface, required a comprehensive transformation to meet the operational standards of a military-grade system.

Understanding the mission-critical nature of the project, Jason began by conducting an in-depth assessment of the existing system. He identified key deficiencies, including unreliable data integration from multiple sources, performance bottlenecks, and a front-end design that failed to comply with Department of Defense (DoD) standards for security, accessibility, and usability.

To address these issues, Jason engineered a robust back-end architecture that integrated data from multiple Postgres databases. This new design optimized data aggregation and ensured scalability, accuracy, and real-time reliability, providing Space Force personnel with a unified and consistent source of information for critical decision-making.

In addition, Jason introduced SignalR to the application, enabling real-time data updates and synchronization. This innovation allowed operators to receive instantaneous updates on weather balloon instrumentation, significantly reducing latency and improving the system's operational efficiency. SignalR also enhanced the application's ability to support live monitoring, an essential feature for dynamic and time-sensitive operations.

Jason also spearheaded a complete redesign of the front end, ensuring it adhered to strict DoD standards. The new interface improved usability, accessibility, and security, streamlining workflows and reducing errors for operators. This redesign not only enhanced the user experience but also aligned the application with the rigorous expectations of military-grade systems.

Through meticulous code refactoring and rigorous testing, Jason delivered a production-ready application that transformed the unreliable, bug-laden system into a stable, scalable, and user-friendly tool. His work significantly improved the Space Force's ability to monitor and analyze atmospheric conditions with precision, providing a platform that was not only functional and reliable but also positioned for future enhancements.

Entities.Name: National Financial Corporation
Entities.Title: Software Architect
Entities.Description:
Jason was brought in to develop a CRM system targeting Low-to-Moderate-Income (LMI) institutions, specifically Check Cashing stores, to streamline their operations and improve customer relationship management. The project started with a prototype written in C# and Angular, which Jason successfully migrated to a more modern and scalable technology stack. He transitioned the system to ASP.NET Blazor, leveraging its real-time interactive capabilities, and integrated Telerik for rich UI components and ReactiveUI for managing the application's complex state and ensuring smooth user interactions. Additionally, Jason developed a prototype MAUI application, tailored for mobile devices, primarily for check-cashing services, enabling users to manage transactions and customer data on-the-go.

The backend for the system was built on Microsoft SQL Server, providing a robust and reliable database platform to store and manage all transactional and customer data. The migration to this stack ensured that the CRM could scale effectively, providing both web and mobile users with fast, reliable access to the system.

Beyond his development work, Jason also took on Enterprise Architect duties. Working closely with the CEO, he helped shape the project's vision by developing UML (Unified Modeling Language) and BPMN (Business Process Model and Notation) diagrams. These diagrams were crucial in modeling both the business and technical use cases, helping to clarify system requirements, map out workflows, and ensure alignment between the technical team and business goals. His ability to bridge the gap between development and strategic business objectives was instrumental in creating a solution that met the unique needs of LMI institutions and their customers.

Through his work, Jason not only developed the core POC/MVP but also ensured that the CRM system was well-architected for future growth, making it an essential tool for the target market of check-cashing stores and other similar institutions.

Entities.Name: MultiPlex.studio
Entities.Title: Coalition Lead
Entities.Description:
MultiPlex.studio was founded with a focus on tackling some of the most pressing challenges in defense and technology, beginning with the AFWERX Multi-Domain Operations (MDO) Challenge. The company was selected as one of the top 100 out of 317 entries to present its solution at the AFWERX Fusion 2019 event in Las Vegas. The solution was centered around Fog Computing, utilizing an extensible microservices architecture that allowed for the seamless integration of features from both first- and third-party providers. This modular approach enabled flexible and scalable systems, meeting the dynamic needs of modern military operations.

Following this success, MultiPlex.studio continued to build on its capabilities and expertise in the defense sector. In 2020, the company participated in the AFWERX Reimagining Energy Challenge focused on Policy and Culture, exploring ways to rethink energy strategies within the defense context. The following year, MultiPlex.studio took part in the 2021 B-52 Mixed Reality Training Workshop, leveraging cutting-edge technologies to explore how mixed reality could enhance military training, specifically for the B-52 bomber. In addition, the company developed a proposal for ROTC (Reserve Officer Training Corps) through the Office of Naval Research (ONR), contributing to the development of future military leaders through innovative training and education models.

Beyond these competitions, MultiPlex.studio contributed to several strategic defense initiatives by preparing whitepapers for the USAF Cyberspace Dominance mission, highlighting the importance of securing the military's cyberspace domain. The company also demonstrated its commitment to addressing national security needs by developing and submitting an RFP (Request for Proposal) to the National Security Agency and responding to an RFI (Request for Information) from the Office of the Undersecretary of Defense for Research and Engineering (USD-R&E). These initiatives showcased MultiPlex.studio's ability to engage with key defense agencies and contribute solutions to the evolving needs of national security and military operations.

Throughout these engagements, MultiPlex.studio has continued to push the boundaries of defense technology and innovation, focusing on areas such as Fog Computing, mixed reality training, cyberspace security, and energy policy, making significant contributions to both the defense industry and broader national security efforts.

Entities.Name: Courseware Coach
Entities.Title: Software Architect
Entities.Description:
Courseware.coach is an AI-driven education platform designed to revolutionize learning through intelligent coaching. The platform leverages state-of-the-art artificial intelligence and cloud technologies to deliver an interactive and personalized learning experience. Users engage with AI-powered digital "clones" of coaches for structured courses and unstructured learning sessions.

The application is built using C# and ASP.NET Blazor, enabling rich, real-time interactive web applications with high performance. The front end is further enhanced with Telerik UI Components, providing professional-grade UI elements for an intuitive user experience. To ensure smooth data flow and reactive interactions, ReactiveUI is used for state management.

On the backend, the platform integrates the Microsoft Bot Framework, allowing for intelligent conversational AI capabilities, alongside Delphi.ai and ChatGPT, which power natural language interactions and personalized coaching experiences. Azure Document Indexer and Azure Document Intelligence are employed for document processing, AI-driven content understanding, and intelligent search capabilities. Data persistence is managed using Entity Framework Core (EF Core).

The platform is architected as a cloud-native solution using Azure Functions for serverless computing, providing scalability and efficiency. Additional AI-driven features, such as speech recognition and text analysis, are powered by Azure Cognitive Services. GitHub Actions is leveraged to automate CI/CD pipelines, streamlining deployment and testing processes.

To maintain a clean and scalable codebase, the system employs key software design patterns, including the Unit of Work & Repository Pattern for structured data access, Microservices Architecture for modularity and scalability, and Dependency Injection to enhance flexibility and maintainability. Through these technologies and best practices, Courseware.coach delivers a seamless, intelligent, and highly effective educational experience.

Key contributions to the platform include designing and implementing a scalable AI-driven educational system, developing a reactive UI architecture with Blazor and ReactiveUI, and integrating cutting-edge AI models such as ChatGPT and Delphi.ai. Additionally, the implementation of GitHub Actions-based CI/CD pipelines ensures robust deployment and continuous development workflows. This role showcases expertise in C#, full-stack development, AI integration, cloud computing, and modern software architecture, demonstrating the ability to build and scale AI-powered applications in the education sector.

Entities.Name: Hangman Tours
Entities.Title: Software Architect
Entities.Description:
Hangman Tours aimed to provide immersive virtual walking tours for their clients, enabling them to experience guided tours remotely. Jason was tasked with rapidly developing an app to bring this concept to life. To achieve this, he built out a cross-platform MAUI (Multi-platform App UI) application, ensuring that the app could be deployed across multiple platforms, including macOS, Windows, Android, and iOS. This provided Hangman Tours with a wide reach, allowing clients to access virtual tours on their preferred devices.

The app leveraged Azure Speech Services to enable interactive audio features, where users could listen to the tour guide's narration as they explored different locations. This functionality made the experience more engaging, as it replicated the audio component of a traditional walking tour. Additionally, Jason integrated the Bing Maps API to provide interactive maps and location-based services, allowing users to navigate through the tour locations virtually. By combining these technologies, Jason was able to offer a seamless, immersive virtual experience that closely mimicked the feel of an in-person walking tour.

The backend of the application was built using C#, Blazor, and ReactiveUI, providing a modern and responsive front-end experience. SQL Server was used as the database to manage tour data, ensuring that information about locations, routes, and user progress was stored efficiently and could be accessed quickly during the tours. With the power of MAUI, Azure Speech Services, and Bing Maps, Jason created a comprehensive and scalable solution for Hangman Tours, enabling them to offer virtual tours on a wide variety of devices and provide a unique, interactive experience for their customers.

Entities.Name: KPMG
Entities.Title: Enterprise Architect - State of New Mexico
Entities.Description:
Jason was brought in to assist with the State of New Mexico's Medicaid Transformation Project, specifically to convert Visio UML diagrams into valid diagrams in Sparx Enterprise Architect. This task involved not just the conversion of visual representations but also ensuring that the data models were accurately structured for integration with MarkLogic's NOLAP schema, which was the data storage and messaging target for the project.

The project required Jason to carefully translate the existing Visio-based diagrams, which were used to model the system architecture, into Sparx Enterprise Architect, a tool known for its advanced capabilities in model-driven development and enterprise architecture. The target data structure, MarkLogic's NOLAP schema, was designed for NoSQL operations, emphasizing efficient querying and handling of semi-structured data. Jason ensured that the translated UML diagrams adhered to the specific requirements of the NOLAP schema, including considerations for both message storage and data storage components. This required attention to both the technical specifications of MarkLogic's architecture as well as the Medicaid project’s unique needs in terms of data management and communication.

Through this effort, Jason played a crucial role in ensuring that the State of New Mexico's Medicaid Transformation Project had a solid, scalable, and correctly structured data architecture that would support both the messaging requirements and complex data storage needs of the Medicaid system. His work contributed to the project’s ability to efficiently handle the large volumes of data and real-time communications necessary for modernizing Medicaid operations.

Entities.Name: 3D PDF Consortium
Entities.Title: StratML Working Group Member
Entities.Description:
The Strategy Markup Language (StratML) is an ISO and ANSI standard designed to express strategic plans in a machine-readable format, providing a framework for systems to share strategic information. The user’s deep interest in strategy and machine-readable formats led them to become a key player in expanding the StratML standard, particularly with the release of StratML 3.5. Their contributions have garnered attention from significant entities such as the U.S. Department of Defense (DoD), which is leveraging StratML 3.5 as part of an initiative to reduce fuel consumption across its departments by 20% before 2022. The goal is to optimize flight plans and aircraft usage, with StratML enabling systems to receive strategic instructions and enforce them across various Command and Control (C2) systems.

The integration solution designed for capturing IRS Form 990 from AWS S3 and transforming it into StratML involved a highly coordinated use of several Azure services to create an efficient and automated workflow. The process began with the retrieval of IRS Form 990 from AWS S3, after which the data was processed through Azure Classic Cloud Services. These services were chosen for their ability to handle the orchestration of the integration logic, providing a platform to interact with and manage the flow of data between various components. Azure Classic Cloud Services enabled the system to run custom business logic that facilitated the smooth processing of the data, ensuring that it could be captured, transformed, and forwarded through the pipeline.

Once the data was retrieved, it was placed into Azure Service Bus Queues. The Service Bus acted as an intermediary layer, providing asynchronous message queuing for communication between different components of the system. This ensured that the transformation process could proceed smoothly without overwhelming the system, as data was processed in manageable chunks. It allowed for decoupling, which meant that the ingestion of data from S3 and the transformation logic could run independently, improving the overall scalability and reliability of the solution.

Following this, the transformed data, now in StratML format, was stored in Azure Cosmos DB using its SQL API. Cosmos DB is a globally distributed NoSQL database, chosen for its ability to handle large volumes of unstructured data at low latency and with high availability. By utilizing the SQL API, Jason ensured that the data was stored in a structured format, allowing it to be queried efficiently. This provided the necessary foundation for managing the strategic data in a way that was both scalable and easily accessible for further processing or analysis.

To make the data more accessible and retrievable, Jason implemented Azure Search, which indexed the stored StratML data. Azure Search is a robust search-as-a-service platform, capable of indexing large amounts of data and providing fast, full-text search capabilities. By indexing the data, it became searchable based on various criteria, such as keywords or metadata, enabling users to quickly retrieve specific strategic information. This powerful search functionality allowed stakeholders to interact with the data in a meaningful way, improving the usability of the system.

Finally, Jason developed an ASP.NET Core 2 application to present the data in a user-friendly manner. The application was designed to allow users to search and view the indexed StratML data, providing a clear and intuitive interface for interacting with complex strategic information. Using ASP.NET Core 2 allowed the application to be fast, scalable, and cross-platform, ensuring that users could access it regardless of their operating system or device. The integration with Azure Search enabled the application to quickly retrieve the relevant information from Cosmos DB and present it in a way that was both structured and easily navigable, making it simple for users to access the insights they needed.

Through this integration, Jason created a solution that not only automated the ingestion and transformation of data into StratML but also built a powerful and scalable architecture for storing, searching, and presenting strategic data. The use of Azure Classic Cloud Services, Service Bus Queues, Cosmos DB, Azure Search, and ASP.NET Core allowed the system to handle complex data requirements efficiently, ensuring that it could scale to meet future needs while maintaining high performance and reliability. This work was instrumental in enabling a more effective and accessible platform for strategic data management and decision-making.

Entities.Name: mil.API.fit
Entities.Title: Chief Transformation Engineer
Entities.Description:
The project focused on Army SBIR A18-030, which aimed to develop advanced data tools for the Army Basic Training Environment. This initiative sought to explore the integration of wearables and Internet of Things (IoT) devices for recruits during Basic Military Training (BMT), allowing for the capture and distribution of biometric data. The ultimate goal was to feed this data into a modeling platform capable of altering training for individual soldiers and groups in real time, while also laying the groundwork for refining unit assignment strategies after graduation. While the project was not selected for the SBIR award, it generated significant interest from the U.S. Air Force (USAF), though this interest did not lead to further collaboration.

The proposed solution was based on a combination of cutting-edge wearables and cloud-based architecture. The team identified wearable devices such as the Empatica E4 and Embrace wristbands, designed to capture vital biometrics like heart rate, temperature, and movement. These devices were chosen for their ability to withstand the tough training conditions while being unobtrusive enough not to interfere with the soldiers’ activities. By collecting data from these wearables, the system aimed to offer insights not just into individual performance but also into the cohesiveness of training groups. This focus on both individual and collective metrics was seen as a way to optimize both the training process and team dynamics within the military environment.

A significant part of the project’s design involved utilizing Service-Oriented Architecture (SOA), with data captured by the wearables being transmitted to an Azure Edge service for real-time processing. This would allow for the data to be sent to Mil Azure, which would then apply artificial intelligence (AI) models to analyze the data and identify performance trends. The system was designed to go beyond simple data capture, enabling instructors to adjust training plans dynamically based on both individual and team performance metrics. With real-time feedback, instructors would be empowered to make data-driven decisions to enhance training effectiveness.

Artificial intelligence and machine learning played a crucial role in the project. The team proposed using AI models to correlate biometric data with training performance metrics, such as the number of sit-ups, push-ups, and run times, to predict future outcomes and improve training effectiveness. In addition to the physical metrics, psychological assessments, such as self-reports on resilience and stress, were also to be integrated, providing a more holistic view of a recruit’s performance. This combination of physical, psychological, and team performance data would enable a deeper understanding of how various factors contribute to success in BMT.

The project also envisioned the creation of a configurable dashboard for training instructors, which would provide them with real-time updates on the recruits' health, physical performance, and psychological well-being. This dashboard would allow instructors to monitor vital signs such as heart rate and temperature and quickly identify any trainees who might be at risk of overexertion or mental breakdowns. The idea was to enable instructors to make immediate adjustments to training, providing a safer and more responsive training environment.

Although the project did not secure the SBIR award, it represented an innovative approach to using technology, wearables, and AI to enhance military training. The concept garnered attention for its potential to not only optimize physical training but also enhance team cohesion and individual performance, offering a more comprehensive model for training the next generation of soldiers.

Entities.Name: Group Bobaloo
Entities.Title: Chief Transformation Engineer
Entities.Description:
Jason co-founded Group Bobaloo with Bob "Bobaloo" Weiss, establishing it as a holding company for a variety of business ventures, both existing and new. Among the businesses under the Group Bobaloo umbrella were Shakers Cigar Bar, Hangman Tours, and the innovative Haunted Suites, which used Airbnb to rent out a haunted penthouse. This unique concept leveraged the growing trend of experiential travel, offering a spooky, immersive stay in a one-of-a-kind location.

As part of the business expansion, Jason and Bob acquired several domain names to promote and support each of these ventures. Notably, ghosts.shop was launched as a retail point of sale for Jason's trademarked merchandise, offering a range of products related to the haunted experience. Additionally, they created cubacontraband.com, an online store selling Cuban cigars and rum and accepting Bitcoin as a payment method. This combination of traditional luxury products with cutting-edge cryptocurrency options highlighted their innovative approach to modern business.

Jason took a hands-on role in developing the technical infrastructure for the Group Bobaloo ventures, particularly focusing on the online presence. He designed a beautiful front-end for the Group Bobaloo main website and built the store fronts using ASP.NET Core, Azure, and CosmosDB. This modern tech stack enabled him to deliver a seamless and responsive shopping experience, ensuring that customers could easily browse and purchase products while taking advantage of the backend scalability and reliability offered by Azure and CosmosDB. Jason’s technical expertise played a pivotal role in the success of these businesses, helping to establish a strong online presence and streamline the operations of these diverse ventures.

Entities.Name: Cyber Safety Harbor
Entities.Title: Chief Transformation Engineer
Entities.Description:
Cyber Safety Harbor, a long-time startup focused on revolutionizing cyber security, was built around two groundbreaking patents that formed the core of its security architecture. The first patent, known as the Hardware Unique Factor (HUD), introduced a hardware key that was crypto-etched onto silicon in a way that made it physically impossible to duplicate, even at a quantum level. The second patent, the Secure Execution Environment, involved isolating a runtime in hardened memory on an external device, preventing the host operating system from accessing or tampering with it. This dual-layered approach represented a quantum leap over traditional security technologies, offering a level of protection that could be considered virtually impenetrable.

In my role at Cyber Safety Harbor, I led efforts to rebrand the company, bringing its cutting-edge architecture into the cloud and identifying key use cases to demonstrate the immense value of the technology. One of the primary projects I worked on was the design and development of a hybrid-cloud solution for Identity and Access Management (IAM), based on the company’s unique security model. This solution combined the traditional strengths of cloud architecture with the advanced, nearly unbreakable security offered by Cyber Safety Harbor’s patented technology. By using the HUD and Secure Execution Environment in a cloud-based model, I ensured that identities could be managed and protected in a way that was not only secure but also scalable and adaptable to a range of enterprise needs.

Additionally, I was responsible for developing an ASP.NET Core 2 application for the company’s in-house Customer Relationship Management (CRM) system. This application streamlined internal processes, allowing teams to better manage customer interactions and data while providing a more seamless and intuitive user experience. The use of ASP.NET Core 2 allowed the application to be efficient, scalable, and cross-platform, ensuring it met the company’s evolving needs as it expanded its customer base and product offerings.

Through these initiatives, I played a key role in modernizing the company’s infrastructure and positioning it for future growth. My efforts helped to demonstrate the potential of Cyber Safety Harbor’s unique security architecture in the cloud, as well as the value it could bring to a wide range of industries requiring cutting-edge cyber protection.

Entities.Name: United Airlines
Entities.Title: Lead Architect - Merchandising IT
Entities.Description:
Jason was brought in to design an innovative Artificial Intelligence solution for United Airlines (UAL) aimed at enhancing the passenger experience and boosting non-airfare merchandise sales. The system was intended to suggest three personalized add-ons to a passenger's ticket—such as extra baggage, economy plus seating, and premier pass upgrades—based on flight details and the user's profile. These recommendations were integrated seamlessly into the passenger's workflow across all channels, including web, kiosk, and partner platforms.

To ensure the solution was both effective and efficient, Jason developed a comprehensive UML diagram in Sparx Enterprise Architect that modeled the entire recommendation workflow. The system was designed to randomly select between two different models: Oracle RTD and a custom AI model. This randomized approach allowed UAL to assess the return on investment (ROI) performance of both models, ensuring that the company could optimize its recommendation engine over time. Once implemented, the AI-driven recommendation system contributed to a significant 30% Quarter over Quarter revenue growth in non-airfare merchandise, directly aligning with the company’s strategic goals.

Beyond the AI recommendation system, Jason also led the development of the United Enterprise Library (UEL), a critical component for standardizing development processes within the organization. The UEL included a multi-provider ORM data layer that supported both Entity Framework and Dapper out of the box, offering flexibility and performance optimization depending on the use case.

In addition to these architectural innovations, Jason created a purchase analysis tool built in ASP.NET MVC. This tool utilized TypeScript and Knockout.js for a dynamic, interactive front end, and Highcharts for powerful, visually engaging data visualizations. The tool provided business analysts with insights into purchase patterns, enabling better decision-making and further enhancing UAL’s ability to target merchandise offers effectively.

Jason’s work not only played a pivotal role in increasing revenue but also laid the foundation for a more scalable and data-driven approach to decision-making at United Airlines, ultimately enhancing both operational efficiency and the passenger experience.

Entities.Name: Hallmark Data Systems
Entities.Title: Lead Architect - Legacy Transformation
Entities.Description:
Hallmark Data Systems, a company specializing in managing magazine subscriptions for clients such as MSDN Magazine, faced the challenge of modernizing its infrastructure. Their operations were dependent on an aging AS/400 mainframe, which limited their ability to implement new features efficiently and hindered client integrations. To address these challenges, Hallmark sought a modern architecture that could streamline development, reduce client onboarding complexity, and expose a syndicated REST API for direct client integration.

Jason spearheaded the design and implementation of a transformative solution. He developed a framework that seamlessly exposed business logic both through RESTful APIs and directly to the database. This dual approach enabled rapid development cycles, allowing the development team to quickly deliver new functionality while ensuring backward compatibility with existing systems. Jason also introduced modern front-end technologies, including Knockout.js, Angular, and TypeScript, which revolutionized the user interface and provided a responsive, interactive experience for users.

The application was built on a customized pipeline for both ASP.NET MVC and ASP.NET Web API, enabling a highly flexible and scalable architecture. To address the recurring needs of data management across the system, Jason designed a domain-specific language (DSL) that allowed REST queries to handle common operations such as paging, filtering, and ordering. This DSL was tightly integrated with a shared gridview component on the front end, standardizing these functionalities across the application while significantly reducing the amount of repetitive code.

Jason’s contributions not only modernized Hallmark’s core infrastructure but also positioned the company to provide enhanced services for its clients. By enabling direct API integration and simplifying client maintenance, his work streamlined operations and paved the way for scalable growth, ensuring that Hallmark could meet the evolving needs of its clients in a rapidly changing digital landscape.

Recommendations.Name: Leszek Zychowski
Recommendations.Body:
Jason Lind has a superb ability to rapidly build highly extensible back-end and front-end 
frameworks. He loves to learn new technologies and is always available to teach his peers 
about the topics he learned. His biggest strength is the fact that he will take an extra step to 
understand the implications of the technology he is implementing in your product.
Recommendations.Title: Application Development Manager

Entities.Name: Guggenheim Partners
Entities.Title: Lead Architect - Asset Management
Entities.Description:
Jason was brought in to unify and modernize a fragmented collection of Microsoft Office-based applications, transforming them into a cohesive ASP.NET MVC/SQL Server portal. This ambitious consolidation project began with the invoicing system, an inefficient patchwork of Excel and Access files that struggled to meet the organization’s needs. Jason quickly designed and implemented a robust platform that not only centralized the invoicing process but significantly enhanced its functionality and user experience.

A hallmark of the new system was its ability to produce pixel-perfect PDF renderings of Excel-based invoice templates. Leveraging Telerik's document library, Jason ensured that the generated invoices preserved the exact formatting and branding required by the organization. This feature dramatically improved the professionalism of invoicing outputs while streamlining the process for end users.

On the front end, Jason introduced TypeScript, a cutting-edge language at the time, to enhance code maintainability and ensure scalability through type safety. Paired with knockout.js for dynamic data binding, this approach modernized the user interface, delivering a more responsive and intuitive experience that exceeded user expectations.

After the successful deployment of the invoicing system, Jason directed his attention to the Credit Monitoring tool. Applying the same principles of consolidation and modernization, he replaced the disparate Office-based workflows with a scalable, integrated web portal. This transformation not only improved efficiency but also established a flexible foundation for future technological growth.

In addition to these initiatives, Jason undertook significant improvements to a critical nightly process known as AutoProc. Originally a tangled VB.NET codebase, AutoProc was prone to errors and inefficiencies. Jason restructured and modernized the process, introducing significant improvements in stability and performance. His enhancements reduced downtime and allowed the organization to better rely on this essential component of their operations.

Through these efforts, Jason consistently delivered solutions that not only addressed immediate challenges but also prepared the organization for sustained success in an increasingly digital environment.

Entities.Name: Mesirow Financial
Entities.Title: Lead Architect - Currency Trading Compliance
Entities.Description:
Mesirow Financial faced a critical need to automate compliance for their currency trading operations, ensuring that trades adhered to the constraints of pegged and hedged transactions as defined by the intricate terms of client-specific currency trading contracts. Jason was brought in to lead a team in designing and implementing a robust solution that addressed these complex requirements with precision and efficiency.

Jason’s team began by developing a sophisticated SQL Server data layer designed to handle the dynamic nature of currency trading contracts. This data layer leveraged database triggers to maintain an auditable history of changes to the underlying data model. The model itself was built with a high degree of abstraction, allowing it to support an unlimited variety of currency contract structures without requiring significant rework. This approach ensured the system's scalability and adaptability to evolving business needs.

The front end of the solution was developed using ASP.NET Web Forms, providing users with a reliable and intuitive interface for managing and monitoring compliance. To facilitate seamless integration with Mesirow's proprietary data systems, Jason’s team syndicated the application’s functionality via Windows Communication Foundation (WCF). This allowed the system to communicate effectively across multiple platforms and maintain real-time compliance checks.

The project also utilized the cutting-edge Entity Framework, which was relatively new at the time, to streamline data access and management. By adopting this technology, Jason ensured that the system could leverage the latest advancements in data modeling and query optimization, improving both performance and maintainability.

Jason’s leadership and technical acumen were instrumental in delivering a scalable and forward-thinking compliance solution, enabling Mesirow Financial to automate critical aspects of their currency trading operations while maintaining strict adherence to client contracts.

Recommendations.Name: Tom McKee
Recommendations.Body:
Jason is an excellent architect and has a strong ability to come up to speed very quickly 
with complex business rules and implement them as high quality software solutions
Recommendations.Title: Vice President

Entities.Name: AlphaMetrix
Entities.Title: Senior Architect - Hedge Fund Networking
Entities.Description:
AlphaMetrix was in the process of developing a groundbreaking hedge-fund networking application designed to connect qualified investors with vetted hedge funds. This platform aimed to combine the networking features of LinkedIn with the trading capabilities of E*Trade, tailored specifically for an exclusive audience of multi-millionaire investors. Jason was brought in at a critical juncture to help the project overcome the challenges of reaching its beta release.

Given the project's fast-paced and constantly evolving requirements, the application featured several innovative architectural elements. One of the most notable was a system allowing pages to be defined using an Excel XML editor, with business logic embedded directly in the database. This approach enabled rapid iteration and adjustments to meet the dynamic needs of the platform’s stakeholders.

Jason played a pivotal role in enhancing the application's ASP.NET lifecycle to support modular, contextual widgets that could be purchased and integrated through an in-app store. This novel feature added a layer of customization and monetization to the platform, enhancing its value proposition for users.

In addition to his hands-on contributions to the architecture and functionality of the application, Jason also took on a leadership role, mentoring a team of over 25 developers. He provided guidance on best practices in .NET development, improving the overall quality of the codebase and fostering a culture of technical excellence. His expertise and mentorship not only helped the team navigate the complexities of the project but also ensured the application was built on a strong and scalable foundation.

Entities.Name: Neuberger Berman
Entities.Title: Lead Architect - High Yield Fixed Income
Entities.Description:
Jason was brought into NB to integrate a cutting-edge Mortgage Default Projection Engine model into an existing application designed to monitor the integrity of bank portfolios from an audit perspective. During the initial requirements analysis, Jason uncovered the broader potential applications for this model, which extended beyond portfolio monitoring. It became evident that the model would also be utilized in Mortgage-Backed Securities (MBS) trading and an innovative "Loan Modification Strategy Fund." This new concept involved purchasing distressed or defaulted debt at heavily discounted rates, modifying the loans through measures like principal reductions, term extensions, and interest rate adjustments, and then reselling the rehabilitated loans at a significant markup. The strategy not only kept homeowners in their homes but also presented a lucrative opportunity, with rehabilitated loans being sold for 60–70 cents on the dollar.

One of the initial challenges Jason tackled was the state of the front-end interfaces for the Bank Integrity applications. Although developed in WPF, these interfaces suffered from poorly structured code, as they did not follow the Model-View-ViewModel (MVVM) design pattern. Jason prioritized refactoring these front ends, implementing MVVM using the Prism framework to separate UI logic and improve maintainability. This update ensured that the front ends were cleaner, more efficient, and aligned with modern development practices, while preserving the Engine’s existing signature to avoid disruptions.

In parallel, Jason developed the new Mortgage Default Projection Engine model. He maintained consistent interfaces to ensure compatibility with existing systems while also enhancing the performance of the older engine by parallelizing its processes. By adopting the Task async/await patterns, which were still in beta at the time, Jason designed the interfaces with future .NET advancements in mind, ensuring the solution was forward-compatible and optimized for scalability. His work not only modernized the existing systems but also positioned the organization to capitalize on emerging opportunities in MBS trading and loan modification strategies, combining technical excellence with business foresight.

Entities.Name: Adventurers Club of Chicago
Entities.Title: Director of Technology
Entities.Description:
The Adventurers Club of Chicago, founded in 1911 by Teddy Roosevelt, stands as a beacon for exploration and daring achievements. Jason played a crucial role in the club’s modernization, handling all technical aspects of its operations. He developed the club’s website, ensuring its storied history and ongoing adventures were effectively showcased to a broader audience. Additionally, he managed the Audio/Visual setup for presentations, facilitating the sharing of extraordinary tales by members and guest speakers with seamless professionalism.

In 2008, at the age of 24, Jason made history as the youngest Resident Member ever inducted into the club. This honor placed him among an elite group of adventurers, including iconic figures such as aviator and explorer Steve Fossett. Jason’s technical expertise and youthful energy brought a contemporary edge to the club, helping to preserve its legacy while ensuring its relevance for future generations.

Entities.Name: Northern Trust Bank
Entities.Title: Senior Architect - Distributed Frameworks
Entities.Description:
Jason was brought into Northern Trust (NTRS) to design and implement the core frameworks required for a seamless migration from .NET 1.1 to .NET 3.5. His efforts resulted in the creation of the Northern Trust Enterprise Library (NEL), a comprehensive and reusable framework that became foundational to the organization's software development processes. Jason rapidly developed a versatile data access framework capable of supporting multiple database platforms, including Oracle, Sybase, IBM DB2, and SQL Server. This provided a consistent and scalable approach to data management, simplifying development efforts across the enterprise. Additionally, he designed a secure encryption module to handle sensitive data, ensuring compliance with stringent security and regulatory standards. 

To enhance reliability and debugging capabilities, Jason implemented an advanced logging system, enabling detailed monitoring and troubleshooting for developers. He also pioneered a one-touch deployment process, which significantly streamlined application release workflows, reducing manual intervention and minimizing the risk of deployment errors. Recognizing the need for more efficient development cycles, Jason drove the requirements and implementation of a Continuous Integration/Continuous Deployment (CI/CD) system built on Team Foundation Server 2008. This initiative introduced automated build and deployment pipelines, improving code quality, development velocity, and overall delivery timelines. 

The NEL framework, designed and implemented under Jason’s leadership, became a critical asset, supporting 800 applications and enabling 14,000 developers globally. This standardized infrastructure not only facilitated the successful migration to .NET 3.5 but also established a robust foundation for ongoing innovation, collaboration, and operational efficiency within the organization.

Recommendations.Name: Chuck Goodspeed
Recommendations.Body: … Jason's superior Architectural skills and design knowledge exemplified the best use of the latest .NET 3.5 capabilities and techniques while adhering to industry accepted patterns and practices... His insightful development of Generic based helper functionality dramatically increased developer productivity and provided a new standard for maintainability. Jason is also a prolific researcher and is poised to help companies move to the next level of architectural design...
Recommendations.Title: Senior Architect

Entities.Name: Aon Benfield
Entities.Title: Senior Solutions Architect
Entities.Description:
Jason was brought back to provide IT support during the complex merger of Aon Re and Benfield Group, a project requiring expertise in integrating diverse technological frameworks. In this capacity, Jason designed an innovative end-to-end solution leveraging the distributed computing platform Condor, which significantly optimized the scalability and efficiency of the system. This solution was instrumental in processing the increased computational demands arising from the merger.

In parallel, Jason significantly enhanced the capabilities of CatRange, a critical component in the workflow, by improving its logging infrastructure. He implemented a sophisticated WPF-based log viewer, providing users with an intuitive interface for monitoring and analyzing application performance in real-time. This enhancement streamlined issue identification and resolution, contributing to greater system reliability.

To further refine data operations, Jason spearheaded the development of a more coordinated ETL (Extract, Transform, Load) process. By utilizing ASP.NET for process orchestration and SQL Server Integration Services (SSIS) for data transformation and integration, he improved data accuracy and processing efficiency. This initiative ensured seamless data flow and alignment between legacy systems and the consolidated infrastructure.

Additionally, Jason continued to support and enhance the application's codebase, which comprised both C# and VB.NET components. His contributions included optimizing existing functionality, introducing new features, and addressing technical debt. This comprehensive support ensured the application met evolving business requirements while maintaining high performance and stability. 

Jason's multifaceted contributions during the merger demonstrated his technical expertise, adaptability, and commitment to delivering robust IT solutions under complex conditions.

Entities.Name: Citadel Investment Group
Entities.Title: Senior Solutions Architect - Hedge Fund Reporting
Entities.Description:
Jason was engaged by Citadel, a leading hedge fund, to work on their eGlue Reporting Application, a mature Windows Forms application with a .NET Remoting service layer. His primary responsibility was to modernize and expand the application’s capabilities, ensuring it remained robust and aligned with the firm’s evolving requirements.

Jason spearheaded the migration of the application’s Remoting layer to Windows Communication Foundation (WCF). This transition enhanced the application’s flexibility, scalability, and interoperability, laying the groundwork for future enhancements while maintaining seamless functionality during the migration process.

To extend the application’s reach, Jason rapidly developed a read-only ASP.NET Web Forms version of the reports. This web-based solution parsed a complex XML-based report definition and integrated it with various datasets, providing Citadel’s stakeholders with easy, browser-accessible insights without requiring the desktop application. His efficient implementation ensured minimal disruption while delivering valuable functionality.

In addition to these contributions, Jason demonstrated his innovative approach by developing a prototype Silverlight reporting application. This proof-of-concept solution was designed to deliver real-time network analytics sourced from a TIBCO Rendezvous Service, showcasing how Citadel could leverage emerging technologies for more dynamic and responsive reporting.

Jason’s work at Citadel reflected his expertise in modernizing legacy systems, integrating diverse technologies, and rapidly delivering high-value solutions. His ability to both refine existing systems and prototype forward-looking applications underscored his technical versatility and alignment with Citadel’s high-performance culture.

Entities.Name: Aon Benfield
Entities.Title: Senior Application Architect - Catastrophic Risk Modeling
Entities.Description:
Aon Benfield (formerly AonRe), one of the world’s largest reinsurance firms, develops products that mitigate catastrophic risks for insurance portfolios. Jason contributed to the development of CatRange, a powerful desktop application designed to process and analyze the complex outputs of industry-standard projection engines like AIR and RMS. These models answered critical questions for insurers, such as estimating potential losses for events like a Category 5 hurricane hitting Miami. By examining data at a granular level, such as by zip code, county, or state, actuaries could gain valuable insights into risk exposure.

CatRange was designed for semi-technical users, allowing them to attach multiple SQL Server databases to the application, configure output parameters, and perform advanced calculations. These calculations, many of which were non-aggregateable—such as beta distributions—were implemented in C# for their computational complexity. The resulting data, generated on a geocoded basis, was exported as CSV files and uploaded into Oracle OBIE for visualization and reporting.

The application itself was built as a Windows Forms application written in VB.NET, while the heavy-lifting calculation engine was developed in C#. Jason played a pivotal role in optimizing the application's performance by introducing an early release of Microsoft’s Task Parallel Library (TPL), a precursor to modern parallel computing frameworks. His innovations in parallelizing the data processing engine dramatically improved the system’s efficiency. Before Jason’s optimizations, processing a typical 1TB data set took several days to complete. After his enhancements, the same workload could be processed in just a few hours, revolutionizing the productivity of actuaries and analysts.

Jason’s work on CatRange not only showcased his ability to blend desktop application development with advanced computational solutions but also highlighted his knack for leveraging cutting-edge technologies to solve real-world problems at scale. His contributions significantly enhanced the application’s utility and performance, making it an invaluable tool for Aon Benfield’s actuarial and risk management teams.

Entities.Name: comScore
Entities.Title: Web Service Architect
Entities.Description:
comScore, a global leader in web analytics, engaged Jason to expand their data accessibility by developing syndicated web services to expose their insights to clients. Jason's primary responsibility was to design and implement an ASP.NET ASMX service that interfaced with their SQL Server Analysis Services (SSAS) cluster. This service enabled clients, including high-profile organizations such as Yahoo!, to seamlessly retrieve and integrate comScore's analytics data into their own systems.

To support client adoption and integration, Jason developed demonstration applications in two distinct environments. The first was a .NET Windows Forms application, showcasing how to consume the ASMX Web Service in a native .NET ecosystem. Recognizing the diverse technological landscapes of comScore’s clients, Jason also created a Java Swing demonstration application. This application illustrated how to call the ASMX Web Service from Java, catering to clients using Java-based systems.

Jason’s work not only extended comScore’s data capabilities but also facilitated smoother client integration across varying technology stacks. His dual-platform approach demonstrated his versatility and commitment to delivering comprehensive solutions that aligned with client needs, solidifying comScore’s reputation as a leader in accessible, syndicated web analytics.

Entities.Name: Triton-Tek
Entities.Title: Lead Software Engineer
Entities.Description:
After excelling as a Senior Software Engineer at TT, Jason was promoted to Lead Software Engineer, where he took on higher responsibilities, leading innovative projects that delivered significant value to clients.

In his first project as a Lead, Jason spearheaded the rapid development of a web-based Construction Scheduler for Town and Country Homes. The application featured an AJAX-rendered drag-and-drop UI, enabling users to create and manage construction schedules with intricate dependencies, such as ensuring tasks like "pouring the foundation" occurred before "building the walls." Jason and his team built an abstract scheduling engine in T-SQL, leveraging stored procedures and cursors to handle complex logic and dependencies efficiently. Additionally, he developed an administrative tool using traditional ASP.NET WebForms, providing users with robust controls for managing schedules and configurations. The project exemplified Jason’s ability to design systems that merged functionality with usability, streamlining operations for a critical business function.

Following this success, Jason led the development of a Corporate Bankruptcy Administration Portal for Phase11 Consultants. This portal addressed the unique challenge of accommodating clients with vastly different data and business logic requirements. Jason designed a flexible and extensible solution that empowered non-technical business users to configure screens and logic as part of the onboarding process. The system was built using ASP.NET WebForms, with heavy reliance on XSD/XML schemas stored in SQL Server, enabling dynamic adaptation to client-specific needs without requiring custom code for each implementation. This approach dramatically reduced development overhead and improved time-to-market for new clients, positioning Phase11 as a leader in its field.

These projects underscored Jason’s ability to lead teams, architect scalable and adaptable solutions, and deliver complex systems that balanced technical sophistication with business practicality. His promotion to Lead Software Engineer was well-earned, and his contributions during this period further solidified his reputation as an innovative and results-driven professional.

Entities.Name: Triton-Tek
Entities.Title: Senior Software Engineer
Entities.Description:
Jason contributed significantly to TT, a boutique consulting company specializing in custom software solutions for small businesses, by delivering innovative and technically sophisticated projects across a variety of domains.

One of Jason’s notable projects was a Windows Forms Peer-to-Peer scraper targeting Ticketmaster. This application utilized an ASP.NET ASMX Web Services backend and a SQL Server database to automate the purchase of configured events. Designed to avoid IP blacklisting, the application was strategically deployed on public terminals such as those at Kinko’s, showcasing Jason’s ability to navigate technical challenges and deliver practical, impactful solutions.

For an educational toys reseller, Jason worked on a system with a PASP backend where ASP controllers rendered XSLT views, integrating seamlessly with a SQL Server backend. His contributions streamlined the application’s functionality and improved its maintainability, enhancing the client’s operational efficiency.

Jason also played a key role in developing an award-winning product site for Bosch Tools USA. This site, built using Microsoft Content Management Server, allowed dynamic ranking and random presentation of links to product resellers, elevating the brand’s online presence and improving customer engagement.

In the logistics domain, Jason enhanced a multi-warehouse shipping optimization application for packaging materials. The application calculated the optimal cost-per-unit and shipping configurations for carts. Jason’s work involved developing a .NET Interop module that interfaced seamlessly with a PHP web application, demonstrating his expertise in integrating diverse technologies to achieve client goals.

Additionally, Jason developed a C# module for a mortgage broker's backend system, enabling data to be rendered in the MISMO (Mortgage Industry Standards Maintenance Organization) standard. This module facilitated compliance with industry standards, improving the broker’s ability to exchange data reliably and efficiently.

Through his diverse contributions, Jason showcased his technical versatility, problem-solving skills, and ability to deliver high-impact solutions tailored to the unique needs of small businesses across industries.

Recommendations.Name: Jeff Rafter
Recommendations.Body: Jason is the superman of developing a robust layered architecture. I have seen him single handedly wield XML like a lightning-rod through the depths of SQL Server and .NET Enterprises to create performant and malleable solutions. If you are not sure what your architecture should look like, call him. He already knows. He fixed it last week.
Recommendations.Title: CIO - MISMO

Recommendations.Name: Carl Franklin
Recommendations.Body: Jason has an excellent knowledge of emerging technology. He can excel in fast-paced environments requiring advanced software design. His best work is in POC environments working out core solution technical challenges
Recommendations.Title: Managing Partner and Solutions Architect

Entities.Name: United States Air Force
Entities.Title: Airman First Class (E3)
Entities.Description:
Jason enlisted in the United States Air Force with the intention of becoming a Computer Programmer, a role secured through a guaranteed job placement. However, due to unresolved credit card debt, he was denied the necessary Top Secret clearance and reassigned to Backshop Test Avionics during Basic Training. His path through training was unconventional—after being recycled twice in Basic Training, Jason persevered and successfully matriculated, demonstrating resilience and determination.

While attending Electronic Principles training at Keesler Air Force Base, Jason’s leadership qualities began to emerge. He graduated from an Airman Leadership class and was appointed as a Green Rope Airman Leader, a position that tasked him with liaising between Military Training Leaders (Blue Ropes) and a flight of 50 first-term Airmen. This role required organizational skill and effective communication, responsibilities that Jason fulfilled while navigating the challenges of military training.

After completing Electronic Principles, Jason advanced to Sheppard Air Force Base for Advanced Avionics training. There, he excelled academically, showcasing his technical aptitude and ability to grasp complex systems. However, despite his intellectual strengths, Jason faced challenges adapting to the regimented lifestyle of the military. Minor discipline issues ultimately led to his discharge with a **General Under Honorable Conditions** status for Failure to Adapt to Military Life.

During his training, Jason’s creativity and analytical thinking were on full display. He conceptualized novel drone designs using vector-thrust propulsion, which eliminated external moving parts, thereby improving reliability and durability. This innovative approach highlighted his ability to think outside traditional paradigms and explore advancements in aeronautical engineering.

In addition to his engineering insights, Jason delved into theoretical mathematics. Through a PowerPoint presentation, he demonstrated that prime number distribution is non-random—a claim that aligns with a classified formal paper by another author, suggesting implications for the P=NP problem. While the formal paper remains classified, Jason’s independent contributions reflect a keen mathematical mind capable of engaging with some of the most challenging questions in computer science and mathematics.

Jason’s Air Force experience, while marked by challenges, underscores his technical and intellectual capabilities, his creative problem-solving, and his ability to innovate in diverse fields.

Entities.Name: itDept
Entities.Title: Enterprise Architect
Entities.Description:
Jason demonstrated advanced technical skills and innovative thinking by translating complex whiteboarded UML designs into precise, standards-compliant UML diagrams using **Sparx Enterprise Architect**. This work required a deep understanding of system design principles and attention to detail to ensure that the visual models accurately represented the system architectures. His efforts streamlined communication and facilitated alignment between stakeholders and development teams.

In addition to his UML expertise, Jason pioneered a new type of 3D modeling paradigm, leveraging tools like **3D Studio Max** and **Maya** to push the boundaries of traditional 3D design. His novel approach introduced a more dynamic and versatile method for creating and visualizing complex models, setting a new standard in the field.

Clients included high-profile organizations such as **GMAC** and **General Dynamics Land Systems**, where his work contributed to mission-critical projects. His ability to bridge traditional design methodologies with cutting-edge tools and innovations showcased his versatility and capability to deliver exceptional results in demanding environments.

Recommendations.Name: Jeff Brock
Recommendations.Body: Jason has worked with me several times in my architecture practice where he helped research emerging technologies and produce technical drawings. He is a self-starter that comes to the table with creative ideas and out of the box thinking. He has a superior intellect and has brought his considerable intelligence to bear on meeting my challenges.
Recommendations.Title: CEO

Entities.Name: Fortis Health Insurance
Entities.Title: Programmer Analyst I
Entities.Description:
Jason was hired directly by the CIO to join the Web team, tasked with spearheading the company’s critical migration from Java to .NET. This role required him to balance maintaining existing J2EE and Classic ASP applications with developing new solutions using ASP.NET, C#, and VB.NET. His contributions played a pivotal role in enhancing the organization’s technical capabilities during a period of significant transformation.

One of Jason’s initial responsibilities was improving a Java-based J2EE application used by insurance agents for quoting and onboarding new customers. The existing system had overly complex logic for rendering policy options, which hindered both usability and performance. Jason analyzed the system thoroughly and implemented a streamlined solution, simplifying the logic to create a more efficient and user-friendly application.

Building on this success, Jason took the lead in designing and developing a Disaster Recovery (DR) application for managing and communicating recovery contact information. Working closely with a non-technical manager, he built the application using ASP.NET Web Forms with a SQL Server backend. Given the limitations of the .NET 1.0 Base Class Library, Jason developed custom components, including an FTP utility, to meet the system’s requirements. His ability to innovate within these constraints demonstrated his resourcefulness and technical acumen.

In addition to these projects, Jason spearheaded the implementation of the W3C Web Accessibility Initiative (WAI), ensuring compliance with federal mandates requiring insurance companies to make their public websites accessible to individuals with disabilities. This involved adapting existing systems to align with accessibility standards, enabling proper interaction for all users and addressing an essential regulatory requirement.

Jason also leveraged Unified Modeling Language (UML) and Rational XDE to design both business and technical solutions, ensuring alignment between organizational objectives and system architecture. On the Java side, he utilized Computer Associates Harvest for change management, maintaining strict control over code updates and deployments.

His work during this period demonstrated not only his ability to adapt to emerging technologies but also his skill in solving complex technical challenges. Jason’s leadership in the migration to .NET, coupled with his commitment to regulatory compliance and accessibility, laid the foundation for the company’s long-term software strategy while addressing immediate business and operational needs.

Entities.Name: Marquette University
Entities.Title: Computational Mathematician
Entities.Description:
Jason secured a rare undergraduate Research Assistant (RA) position in the esteemed lab of Dr. Joseph Majdalani, a prolific researcher specializing in the study of gas flow dynamics in solid rocket propulsion engines. Dr. Majdalani's team focused on deriving exact and analytic solutions to boundary equations critical to the internal design of rocket engines, utilizing the complex Navier-Stokes differential equations.

In his role, Jason provided general lab support, gaining valuable exposure to high-level research while utilizing office space for his projects. Beyond his supporting responsibilities, Jason made a pivotal contribution by developing an application in **Java** and **Matlab** that transformed the research process. The application was designed to graph analytic solutions to boundary equations, enabling the team to visually distinguish between trivial and non-trivial solutions. This graphical insight significantly enhanced the team's ability to interpret and validate theoretical models.

Jason’s work proved instrumental in solving a 50-year-old problem in the field, a breakthrough that was published in a major scientific journal.
