His ability to integrate computational tools with theoretical research showcased a rare combination of technical skills and scientific insight, leaving a lasting impact on the lab’s research and the broader field of aerospace engineering.

Entities.Name: Mo's Restaurant Group
Entities.Title: Chief Software Architect
Entities.Description:
Jason was hired by the owner of Mo's Restaurant Group to lead the development of an innovative **Software as a Service (SaaS)** product, dubbed the "Enterprise Restaurant Management System." This ambitious product aimed to revolutionize the restaurant industry by integrating four core modules: **Reservations**, **Seating**, **Order Management**, and **Kitchen Management.** 

A standout feature of the system was a **dynamic re-seating algorithm**, which allowed hostesses to optimize table assignments based on real-time reservation data and customer relationship status. This functionality ensured that valued regulars received premium seating, such as tables by the window, fostering loyalty and enhancing the dining experience.

Jason delivered a **multi-tenant application** built using **Java** and **MySQL**, with a **Swing-based front end** and a **Remote Method Invocation (RMI)** web service backend. The application successfully implemented key features, including the re-seating algorithm, and showcased his ability to integrate complex functionalities within a unified system.

As Jason's first foray into dynamic software engineering, the project was a significant learning experience. While he rapidly developed a functional product, several architectural decisions limited the system's scalability, making it challenging to adapt as the business grew. These challenges ultimately led to the codebase being retired. Recognizing the value of the envisioned features, Mo's Restaurant Group pivoted to purchase **Guestbridge**, an established product, and incorporated the re-seating functionality Jason conceptualized into its framework. Guestbridge was later acquired by **OpenTable**, further validating the importance of the features Jason helped design.

This experience underscored Jason's ability to innovate and deliver functional software while highlighting the importance of scalable architecture in enterprise-level applications—a lesson that shaped his approach to future projects.

Entities.Name: CompUSA
Entities.Title: Senior Sales Engineer
Entities.Description:
CompUSA was a leading computer retailer known for offering pre-built systems from top manufacturers such as HP, Compaq, Sony, and Apple. While hardware sales were a primary focus, the company placed significant emphasis on services like setup, support, and extended warranties, which enhanced customer satisfaction and boosted revenue.

Jason excelled in this environment, demonstrating a unique ability to not only sell the hardware but also effectively position and sell the accompanying services. These services included technical support, system customization, and extended service plans that provided long-term value to customers. Jason's approach emphasized understanding customer needs and presenting service solutions that complemented their hardware purchases.

Throughout his entire tenure at CompUSA, Jason consistently led the region in service volume per hour, a metric that highlighted his exceptional efficiency and effectiveness. This achievement underscored his ability to deliver high-quality results in a fast-paced, customer-focused retail setting. Jason’s performance not only contributed to the company’s bottom line but also helped establish a standard for service excellence in his region.

Entities.Name: Freedows OS Project
Entities.Title: Administrative Lead
Entities.Description:
The Freedows OS Project was an ambitious initiative aimed at creating a versatile Operating System based on Kenneth Dudda's "Stanford Cache Kernel." Its design centered on a micro-kernel architecture that would enable a modular emulation layer, allowing native code written for various operating systems—including Windows, MacOS, Linux, and even Amiga—to run seamlessly. 

During its peak, the project boasted more than 4,000 registered members, with Jason leading the non-OS operations. Under his leadership, over 3,500 individuals from around the globe contributed to the project's broader initiatives, showcasing his ability to manage and coordinate a diverse, distributed team effectively. One of Jason's key achievements was spearheading the Translation Team, which successfully localized the project’s website and message board into nearly 25 languages, maintaining an impressive turnaround time of less than 48 hours. Additionally, he oversaw the development of an early textual search engine, enhancing user access to project resources and discussions—a significant technological milestone at the time.

In 1999, the project faced a pivotal moment when a faction of developers broke away to form the ReactOS project, which focused on building a Windows-compatible OS. Following this split, Jason was promoted to co-Lead of the Freedows OS Project. Despite this promotion and the eventual development of a prototype kernel, the project struggled to fully realize its ambitious goals. However, Jason's leadership and the team’s achievements during this period remain a testament to the innovative spirit and collaborative effort that defined the project.

Recommendations.Name: Reece Sellin
Recommendations.Body: Jason consistently demonstrated his excellence in all areas of his work at Freedows, but even more strongly so in terms of project management and conceptual design…Although he sometimes has a very unorthodox way of approaching IT-related and project-related challenges, he is the type of individual that consistently exceeds expectations even in the most demanding (and even hostile) of situations.
Recommendations.Title: Project Lead

Entities.Name: Milwaukee PC
Entities.Title: Sales Engineer
Entities.Description:
Jason began his career at the company on the assembly line, where his skills and dedication quickly caught the attention of his supervisors. Within just a month, he was promoted to the role of Sales Engineer. In this position, Jason was responsible for designing and delivering custom computer builds tailored to the specific needs of his retail customers. He also took on computer service tasks, demonstrating his technical expertise and commitment to customer satisfaction.

Despite working only 20 hours per week, Jason became the top-performing salesperson in the company. Over nearly three years, he achieved an extraordinary milestone, generating more than $10 million in revenue. His success was driven by his deep technical knowledge, ability to connect with customers, and knack for identifying and fulfilling their needs.

Jason’s sales responsibilities extended beyond custom computer systems and peripherals. He also sold NexTEL service, Milwaukee PC ISP, and Roadrunner broadband, diversifying his sales portfolio and showcasing his ability to navigate multiple product lines. Additionally, Jason gained valuable experience in outside sales, which included conducting cold calls to expand the company’s customer base and build new business relationships.

This combination of retail and outside sales experience, along with his proven track record of success across diverse product offerings, highlighted Jason’s versatility and ability to deliver exceptional results in a competitive market.

Entities.Name: GeoCities
Entities.Title: Community Leader /Hollywood
Entities.Description:
GeoCities was a trailblazer in the early days of the internet, providing a platform for users, or "homesteaders," to create their own websites using HTML, JavaScript, and CSS—all for free. The platform's unique "neighborhood" structure encouraged users to build websites aligned with the themes of specific online communities, fostering creativity and collaboration. 

In an equity-compensated role at GeoCities, Jason took on the responsibility of patrolling over 50,000 homesteader sites to ensure adherence to content guidelines, promoting a safe and engaging community. Beyond moderation, Jason was a key resource for users, offering support with their HTML and JavaScript challenges, which empowered many to hone their web development skills in the nascent days of the internet.

One of Jason's most notable contributions was his advocacy for inclusivity among younger users. Recognizing the enthusiasm of underaged homesteaders, Jason persuaded the CEO to continue allowing users under the age of 13 to participate, provided they obtained parental permission via fax. This approach not only preserved the creativity of young netizens but also laid groundwork that was later codified in U.S. federal law, becoming a cornerstone of online child protection policies.

Jason's personal GeoCities website, **Hollywood/7524**, stood out as a cultural touchstone of its time. Titled "The Unofficial Simpsons Page," it gained widespread acclaim and was featured on Yahoo!'s TV/Simpsons directory, even ranking above Fox’s official site from 1995 to 1999. This recognition underscored Jason’s ability to blend technical expertise with engaging content creation, solidifying his legacy as a pivotal figure in the early internet era.
